en.teaching_intro_1: Writing or editing articles for Participedia can be a great assignment for courses that deal with political participation, democratic innovation, or deliberation.
en.teaching_intro_2: In the course of selecting, researching, and writing up a case, method, or organization, students will learn about the substance of participation in varied contexts. Students may also find it rewarding to have their work showcased on Participedia.
en.resources_intro: Participedia’s Teaching Training and Mentoring Committee has collected a variety of resources from the academic community. Feel free to adjust the material to suit your class’s needs.
en.community_intro: Participedia is a research partnership representing institutions and organizations around the world. The team produced Participedia.net as a tool to connect their research and bolster it with publicly crowdsourced knowledge about democratic innovations. All members of the Participedia community are integral to this process. The initial vision for Participedia was developed by Archon Fung (Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University) and Mark E. Warren (Department of Political Science, University of British Columbia), and is guided by a set of standing committees.
en.operations,: support the community and ensure project goals are being met.
en.partners_intro: Participedia reflects partnerships with organizations, institutions and individuals across the globe who share an interest in participatory politics and governance. Participedia’s partners are co-signers to the current SSHRC Partnership Grant. Please contact us if you would like to discuss developing a partnership to support Participedia’s global mission.
en.committees_intro: Committees are comprised of project co-investigators and collaborators, each with one nominated chairperson who sits on the executive committee.
en.members_intro: Community members include policy analysts, democratic theorists, scholars, teachers, practitioners, activists, government officials, journalists and more. Anyone can join and help to build this growing resource by editing existing content or publishing new examples of public participation.
en.about_intro: A global community sharing knowledge and stories about public participation
en.about_involved_1: Anyone can {communityLink}  and help crowdsource, catalogue and compare participatory political processes around the world. All content on Participedia is collaboratively produced and open-source under a {ccLink}.
en.community_text_1: Participedia’s searchable database of democratic innovations is made up of three distinct content types including Cases, Methods and Organizations. Bolstering this knowledge base are added resources, including surveys, teaching tools and external data sets.
en.community_text_2: The initial vision for Participedia was developed by Archon Fung (Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University) and Mark E. Warren (Department of Political Science, University of British Columbia), and is guided by a set of standing committees.
en.explore_intro: Search, read, download and gain insight from our database of {caseLink}, {methodLink}, {orgLink}, surveys, teaching resources and external data sets.
en.contribute_intro: Help improve the quality of this knowledge resource by editing existing content or {publishLink}.
en.teach_intro: Use {teachLink} as a tool to engage students and showcase their research.
en.staff_intro: Participedia employs a core staff to maintain day to day operations, support the community and ensure project goals are being met.
en.jesi_carson_org_2: Emily Carr University of Art + Design
en.mark_warren_org_1: Department of Political Science / Centre for the Study of Democratic Institutions
en.executive_committee_intro: Participedia’s executive committee is the decision-making entity for project activities that require close coordination. It is comprised of the chairs of Participedia’s standing committees. Any members of our extended team who are co-signatories to the project’s {sshrcLink} (i.e., co-investigators, collaborators, and administrative representatives of partner institutions) may ask to participate in meetings of the executive committee.

en.teaching_training_committee_intro: The Teaching Training and Mentoring Committee is responsible for developing outputs and implement actions for the integration of Participedia materials into pedagogy, teaching, student involvement and the training of practitioners and public officials.
en.research_design_committee_intro: The Research Design Committee is responsible for setting the strategic direction of PPedia’s research agenda.
en.dt_committee_intro: The Design & Technology Committee is responsible for the design and maintenance of the Participedia website.
en.comms_know_intro: The Communication and Knowledge Mobilization Committee is responsible for advising the Executive Committee on how communication with research partners can be planned, carried out, and refined. The CKM committee also advises on optimal communication with the Participedia user community, including supporting the development of content for the website, newsletter, and social media channels.
en.scott_fletcher_org_1: Department of Political Science / Centre for the Study of Democratic Institutions
en.funders_intro: Participedia is currently supported by the {sshrcLink2} (SSHRC) in the form of a five-year Partnership Grant beginning in April 2015. A two-year SSHRC Partnership Grant was originally provided in April 2011. In 2012, The {bertelsmannLink} provided generous support for development of multi-language functionality.
en.sshrc: Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada
en.content_intro: Participedia offers a searchable database of content related to worldwide public participation.
en.cases_content: Cases are events and instances of participatory politics and governance of all shapes and sizes.
en.methods_content: Methods are the processes and procedures used to guide participatory politics and governance.
en.organizations_content: Organizations are profiles of formal and informal groups that design, implement, or support innovations in participatory politics and governance.
en.research_intro: Participedia is guided by the research question: What kinds of participatory processes work best, for what purposes, and under what conditions?
en.methodology_intro_1: The strategy is simple: crowdsource data on democratic innovations from around the world and then aggregate this into a public database that continually updates with new contributions. All of Participedia’s content and data is open source.
en.methodology_intro_2: For an in-depth explanation of the history, aspirations, theory and analytical approach of Participedia, see {methodologyLink}, by the two founders of Participedia, Archon Fung and Mark E. Warren.
en.data_repository_intro: A great deal of research on democratic innovations is not publicly available. This includes large datasets, graduate and postgraduate dissertations, and practitioner evaluations and reports. We aim to find a home for such research in an accessible data repository.
en.data_repository_link: Dataset on Brazilian Participatory Budgeting: 1989 to 2012
en.surveys_text_1: Surveys are supplementary to Participedia’s current data and narrative descriptions and are intended to gain further insight on the outcomes and effects of cases.
en.surveys_text_2: The participant survey will capture the experience of participants directly involved in a participatory process. It could be delivered by organizers at the location of a particular process, or participants could be asked to complete the survey after the event.
en.surveys_text_3: The observer survey will capture views pertaining to the broader impact of a particular case. ‘Observers’ include practitioners, participants or researchers with particular knowledge of that case.
en.surveys_text_4: Participedia's surveys are undergoing testing, and will be available for download soon.
en.legal_intro: Terms of Use / Privacy Policy for Participedia.net
en.legal_intro_1: Please read this Privacy Policy and Terms of Use carefully (collectively referred to herein as the “Policy”). By using Participedia.net (the “Site”), you as a user of the Site are agreeing to be bound by the terms of this Policy and represent and warrant that you are the age of majority in your area of residence. If you are accepting these terms on behalf of a corporation or other legal entity, then you represent and warrant that you have the authority to bind such entity to these terms
en.legal_intro_2: The Site is hosted by The University of British Columbia, Canada (“UBC”) with administrative and policy support from other institutions (the “Collaborating Institutions”) (collectively, UBC and the Collaborating Institutions are referred to herein as “Participedia”, “us” or “we”).
en.privacy_collection: Privacy and Collection/Use of Personal Information
en.privacy_collection_1: We have adopted this Privacy Policy to explain what information may be collected on the Site, how we use this information, and under what circumstances we may disclose the information to third parties. We respect your privacy and are committed to protecting personally identifiable information you may provide us through the Site unless you consent to its disclosure.
en.privacy_collection_2: Types of information we collect from the Site are as follows:
en.privacy_collection_3: Cookies – In a similar fashion as other websites, Participedia.net uses cookies to improve your experience on the Site and to collect anonymous information about how you use the Site. This information is compiled into anonymous traffic analytics, and is not available to the general public. However, cookies are not required for use of the Site. If your browser is configured not to accept cookies, you will still be able to access the Site and its content.
en.privacy_collection_4: Account information and Activities – We keep a log of the IP addresses of non-registered users.
en.privacy_collection_5: For registered users, in addition to a log of IP addresses we keep a record of their login and logouts, and activities on the site. We keep email address, username, and all the publically available information they choose to provide in their User Account (as herein defined), including: Full Name, Job Title, Profession, Picture, IP Addresses, Biography.
en.privacy_collection_6: Once a user creates or edits content, the contribution, time/date, and username are recorded and may be available to the public indefinitely. Deleting text does not delete the record of the contribution, and previous versions of articles are available indefinitely. Registered users can edit their own username. At your request, you may request the Site administrator at info@participedia.net to cancel/disable your account. When cancelling a User Account the site administrator, at its sole discretion, has the following options:
en.privacy_collection_7:
• Disable the account and keep its content. (default)
  • Disable the account and label its content as belonging to the site’s generic username “Anonymous.”
  • Disable the account and unpublish its content.
  • Disable the account and delete its content.
en.privacy_collection_8: By disclosing your contact information or any other personally identifiable information available to the Site, you are consenting to the disclosure of this information to authorized personnel in UBC, the Collaborating Institutions, and their respective third party service providers, some of which are located outside Canada, for purposes connected with administering the Site. We do not make this information available to anyone else unless we are legally authorized to do so.
en.privacy_collection_9: In addition to the above, we collect certain anonymous (non-personally identifiable) information to help us improve the Site and to evaluate the access, use and the impact of Participedia materials and the Site:
en.privacy_collection_10:
• We collect information you provide about your use of and satisfaction with the Site through emails you send us and through the Site surveys, whether or not you voluntarily include your contact information. Occasionally, we report quoted feedback from users. We do not attribute feedback to specific individuals unless we obtain permission to use that person's name along with the feedback
  • When we report information about the Site’s access, use, and impact, we report aggregate, non-personally identifiable data.
en.privacy_collection_11: Keeping Your Information Secure – We have implemented security measures we consider reasonable and appropriate to protect against the loss, misuse and alteration of the information under our control. Please be advised, however, that while we strive to protect your personally identifiable information and privacy, we cannot guarantee or warrant the security of any information you disclose or transmit to us online and we are not responsible for the theft, destruction, or inadvertent disclosure of your personally identifiable information.
en.privacy_collection_12: Use of Public Forums – We may offer blogs, message boards, bulletin boards, or similar public forums where you and other users of the Site can communicate. The protections described in this Privacy Policy do not apply when you provide information (including personal information) in connection with your use of these public forums. Any information you share in a public forum is public information and may be seen or collected by anyone, including third parties that do not adhere to our Privacy Policy. We are not responsible for events arising from the distribution of any information you choose to publicly post or share through this Site.
en.privacy_collection_13: Legislative Authority – We collect the foregoing personal information under the authority of section 26(c) of the Province of British Columbia’s Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act (“FIPPA”) and we will use, disclose and protect this information as required under the FIPPA. If you have any questions about the collection, use, disclosure and protection of your personal information, contact info@participedia.net.

en.welcome_message: Participedia is a global community sharing knowledge and stories about public participation.
en.help_q1_p1: Cases are events and instances of participatory politics and governance of all shapes and sizes.
en.help_q2_p1: Methods are the processes and procedures used to guide participatory politics and governance.
en.help_q3_p1: Organizations are profiles of formal and informal groups that design, implement, or support innovations in participatory politics and governance.
en.help_q4_p1: Surveys are supplementary to Participedia’s current data and narrative descriptions and are intended to gain further insight on the outcomes and effects of cases. Completed surveys are linked to corresponding cases. See the research page for more information about surveys.
en.help_q5: How do I create a user account?
en.help_q5_p1: Click “sign in” on the main menu and register with an email address or sign in with Google, Facebook or LinkedIn.
en.help_q6_p1: Once you are signed in, you can create content by clicking the “quick submit” button from the main menu and choosing the type of article you would like to create.
en.help_q7_p1: Clicking quick submit allows you to publish a case, method or organization in minutes, without completing a full entry.
en.help_q8: How do I save my draft entry?
en.help_q8_p1: If your new article is not yet ready to publish, click the “save” button to return later. Saved content can be found on your personal profile page.
en.help_q9_p1: While viewing a case, method or organization article, click the edit button to jump in and add to or amend the current entry.
en.help_q10: Can I see who has edited my content?
en.help_q10_p1: The revisions button allows you to display of all the contributions to an article, including authorship, and allows you to revert to a previous version.
en.help_q11: How do I create content in another language?
en.help_q11_p1: If you create an article in a language other than English, please indicate the language in parenthesis right after the name of the article - e.g. “Orcamento Participativo (Portuguese)”.
en.help_q12: Can I translate existing content into another language?
en.help_q13: How do I search for content?
en.help_q13_p1: By default, the homepage search results section displays a curated set of featured content. Explore the homepage map to find content by location.
en.help_q13_p2: Use the search bar at the top of any page to conduct a site-wide search using one or more keywords. Once your search results are displayed, sort the results by content type such as cases, methods or organizations.
en.help_q13_p3: To conduct an advanced search, use the following syntax:
en.help_q13_p4: bicycle and rally (this is the default, so the same as bicycle rally) will return items which match both words
en.help_q13_p5: bicycle or rally will match items with either or both words
en.help_q13_p6: bicycle not rally will match items which contain bicycle, but only if they do not also contain rally
en.help_q13_p7: womens rights will return items that have womens followed by rights
en.help_q13_p8: (bicycle or rally) and (womens rights and UK) will will group logical operations inside the parentheses as a group before applying the operators joining groups
en.help_q14: How do I download and interpret data from my search results?
en.help_q15: How do I access my bookmarked content?
en.help_q15_p1: Visit your personal profile page to access your bookmarked content.
en.no_content_yet_1: You haven't added any content yet. Creating content in Participedia is easy. Try
en.no_content_yet_2: to add a case, a method or an organization.
en.no_bookmarks_yet_1: You don't have any bookmarks yet. Look for this icon
en.name: Name
en.organization_text: You can connect your profile to an organization that is published on Participedia. Begin typing on the organization field below and select the organization from the dropdown list. Or, if you think your organization belongs on Participedia, publish it now by clicking Quick Submit.

en.case_description_instructional: The following standard structure makes it easier to compare and analyze entries. Please use the headings below and refer to our guidelines as you prepare your case entry.
en.location_instructional: Type to search for known location
en.location_placeholder: Type to search for a known location
en.time_limited_instructional: Did this case take place over a single, defined period of days, weeks or months? Or was the entire process repeated over time? Select one.
en.time_limited_placeholder: Was this time limited, or repeated?
en.purposes_instructional: Select and rank up to three purposes, with “1” indicating the most relevant.
en.approaches_instructional: Select and rank up to three approaches, with “1” indicating the most relevant.
en.public_spectrum_instructional: Which type of goal from the IAP2 Spectrum of Public Participation does this case best represent?
en.open_limited: Open to all or limited to some?

en.open_limited_placeholder: Was this open to all or limited to a subset of the population?

en.targeted_participants_instructional: Select up to three of the most heavily recruited groups.
en.process_methods_instructional_case: What methods were used in this case? Type to select methods that already exist in Participedia. For new methods, first publish this case to save your work then publish a new method. To add your new method, return to edit this case.

en.legality_instructional: Is the overall method used in this case considered legal by judicial authorities?
en.facilitators_instructional: Did facilitators help guide part or all of this case?

en.learning_resources_instructional: What type(s) of background information were provided for participants?”
en.if_voting_instructional: What voting method(s) were used by participants?
en.decision_methods_instructional: How did participants in this case make group decisions?
en.insights_outcomes_instructional: Select up to three ways that insights and outcomes from this case were communicated to the intended audiences.
en.primary_organizers_instructional_case: Who was primarily responsible for organizing / managing the initiative? Type to select name of any organization that already exists on Participedia. en.best_for_instructional: What is this method best used to accomplish?
en.issue_interdependency_instructional: What level of issue interdependency can the method handle?
en.issue_interdependency_box_text: Issues may be relatively discrete and can be addressed in isolation from other issues. An example would be a neighborhood decision about appropriate playground equipment for a park. Or issues can be highly interdependent. An example would be global climate change, which involves environmental, economic, cultural, and justice issues.
en.issue_polarization_instructional: What level of issue polarization can the method handle?
en.issue_polarization_box_text: The lowest polarization exists when the process can assume basic agreement on goals. The high polarization exists when participants enter the process with long-standing animosities and low trust.
en.issue_technical_complexity_instructional: What level of technical complexity can the method handle?
en.issue_technical_complexity_box_text: An example of low technical complexity might be resolution of a neighborhood dispute. An example of high complexity would be heath care system reform or global climate change.
en.communication_outcomes_instructional: How are the insights and outcomes from this method typically communicated to the intended audiences?
en.communication_outcomes_box_text:
Examples of Artistic Expression include political rap, street theater, etc.

Examples of Traditional Media include television, radio, newspapers, etc.

Examples of New Media include social media, blogging, texting, etc.

Independent Media is media that is free of corporate or government influence.

Example of a Minority Report could be a dissenting opinion.
en.aggregation_of_individual_preferences_to: Aggregation of Individual Preferences to Create Survey Data
en.unknown_decision: Unknown (i.e., we don’t know how decisions were made
en.voting_decision: Voting (i.e., any type of formal vote; please provide more detail in next field)
en.the_decision_was_made_through_public_del: The decision was made through  public deliberation
en.decisions_are_made_by_the_officials_pres: Decisions are made by the officials presiding over the hearing.
en.consensus_voting_when_consensus_is_not_a: Consensus; voting when consensus is not attained
en.there_are_many_ways_in_which_citizen_adv: There are many ways in which Citizen Advisory Boards make decisions.
en.several_solutions_are_proposed_and_then_: Several solutions are proposed and then discussed
en.most_cases_unanimous_decision_by_voting: most cases unanimous decision by voting
en.user_decisions_are_made_through_a_stance: User decisions are made through a stance slider tool
en.list_of_solutions_narrowed_into_several_: list of solutions narrowed into several proposals during final large group discussion
en.forum_voting_proportions_are_used_to_inf: Forum voting proportions are used to influence decisions by elected representatives.
en.summary_of_comments_in_a_report: summary of comments in a report
en.consent_governs_policy_decisions_in_a_so: Consent governs policy decisions in a sociocratic organization.
en.voting_with_ad_hoc_decision_rule_and_leg: Voting with ad hoc decision rule and legitimacy
en.proxyvoting_on_highest_value_proposals_a: Proxy-voting on highest value proposals at given intervals. Highest-valued proposals from the proposal market are taken to a voting stage where all users votes are considered
en.current_popup_art_practices_focus_on_com: Current pop-up art practices focus on community and social capital building rather than decision making.  Future practices in pop-up democracy could change this trend.
en.voting_geared_toward_consensusdevelopmen: Voting geared toward consensus-development; sometimes in discreet stages
en.polling_to_show_consent_and_collect_para: polling to show consent and collect paramount objections.
en.made_by_the_fws_or_nmfs_after_critical_r: Made by the FWS or NMFS after critical review of an HCP
en.each_city_has_a_different_way_of_going_a: Each city has a different way of going about voting on their decisions. Majority of decisions are made through polls/voting
en.participants_express_their_collective_op: Participants express their collective opinions (through the final Auditor's report) to county government for their internal consideration and analysis.
en.desicision_and_suggestions_are_construct: Desicision and suggestions are constructed through consensus
en.the_state_government_takes_the_publics_c: The state government takes the public's consensual health care policy concerns into consideration
en.1_always_isolated_and_usually_not_tied_t: 1 - Always Isolated and Usually Not tied to Other Issues
en.collaborative_delivery_of_public_service: Collaborative delivery of public services with public authorities
en.numerous_facetoface_small_group_dialogue: Numerous face-to-face small group dialogues of 4-12 people each
en.direct_or_through_communities_of_practic: Direct  or through communities of practices
en.effective_communication_with_experts_and: Effective communication with experts and lay citizens
en.another_name_for_sociocracy_see_method_s: Another name for sociocracy - see method Sociocracy for information
en.online_and/or_face_to_face_conversation: Online and/or Face to face conversation
en.online_via_internet_and_mobile_using_ide: Online via internet and mobile using idea market and proxy-voting
en.online_based_many_to_many_web_based_inte: online based - many to many web based interactions
en.information_market_users_are_both_pitchi: Information market: Users are both pitching new proposals
en.interpersonal_deliberation_and_strengthe: Interpersonal Deliberation and Strengthening Community Associations
en.public_presentation_to_county_government: Public presentation to county government; County Auditor releases report of opinions and values of participants; press release to local media; independent media coverage; Twitter and Facebook updates
en.each_local_government_has_their_own_webs: Each local government has their own website to spread the word locally
en.public_events_are_publicized_via_social_: Public events are publicized via social media and traditional media.
en.popup_democracy_is_itself_a_model_for_pu: Pop-up democracy is itself a model for public interaction.
en.solutions_to_public_policy_issues_are_cr: Solutions to public policy issues are created and assessed
en.all_forum_members_are_invited_to_partici: All forum members are invited to participate
en.a_public_notice_must_be_issued_by_fws_or: A public notice must be issued by FWS or NMFS in the Federal Register
en.citizen_advisory_boards_typically_commun: Citizen Advisory Boards typically communicate their findings to local government officials.
en.this_method_uses_different_organizations: This method uses different organizations to promote their goal. Each organization typically conducts some sort of public gathering for conversation/deliberative
en.expert_analysis_media_releases_legislati: Expert Analysis; Media Releases; Legislative Agenda Setting
en.most_of_the_consensus_conference_was_ope: Most of the consensus conference was open to the media and the public
en.the_media_often_covers_parliamentary_hea: The media often covers parliamentary hearings
en.attending_the_announcement_of_reccomenda: Attending the announcement of reccomendations at the end of the event 2. Reading or viewing the media's coverage of the event
en.results_are_communicated_through_a_publi: Results are communicated through a public hearing and a written report is available to the public and media.
en.users_pro_and_con_lists_are_posted: Users pro and con lists are posted
en.the_main_purpose_of_socratic_cafés_is_no: The main purpose of Socratic Cafés is not to broadcast decisions to the public
en.depends_on_the_organization/citizens_who: Depends on the organization/citizens who host the World Cafe
en.citizens_of_the_community_interested_in_: Citizens of the community interested in Oregon's health care policies gather in a forum to provide input on their values concerning medical practice guidelines
en.workshop_facilitators_or_experts_report_: Workshop facilitators or experts report to media outlets and decision-makers.
en.feedback_may_be_provided_to_community_en: Feedback may be provided to community engagement organisers if the meeting is related to a specific project
en.announcement_of_results_at_each_level: Announcement of results at each level
en.suggest_tag: Add tags to make your submission easy to find (e.g. OIDP2017)
en.governance_political_institutions_eg_con: Governance & Political Institutions (e.g. Constitutions, Legal Systems, Electoral Systems)
en.send_email_with_catgeory_additions: If you believe we should add some categories or specific topics, please email info@participedia.net
en.specific_topics_instructional: Rank order up to three of the most relevant, specific topics, with “1” indicating the most relevant topic.

The following standard structure makes it easier to compare and analyze entries.

We recommend you use the headings below and refer to our guidelines as you prepare your case entry.

To view the guidelines, copy and paste this URL into your browser: https://goo.gl/V2SHQn
en.is_component_of: Make this case a component of another case
en.recruitment_method: Recruitment method for limited subset of population
en.i_am_a_professional_academic_researcher: I am a professional academic researcher
en.i_am_an_undergraduate_student_researcher: I am an undergraduate student researcher
en.i_am_a_graduate_student_researcher: I am a graduate student researcher
en.i_helped_run_the_process_as_a_facilitato: I helped run the process (as a facilitator, staff, etc.)
en.i_was_an_observer_of_the_process: I was an observer of the process
en.i_am_a_representative_of_a_stakeholder_g: I am a representative of a stakeholder group
en.i_am_a_specialist_on_the_issue: I am a specialist on the issue
en.i_am_interested_in_politics_but_have_no_: I am interested in politics, but have no direct connection to this case
en.organization_eg_a_local_business_or_coop: Organization (e.g. a local business or cooperative using participatory methods to manage and govern itself)
en.a_single_defined_period_of_time: A single, defined period of time
en.make_influence_or_challenge_decisions_of: Make, influence, or challenge decisions of government and public bodies
Make, influence, or challenge decisions of private organizations (e.g., civil society organizations; corporations)
en.deliver_goods_and_services_eg_coproducti: Deliver goods and services (e.g., co-production of public safety by police and community)
en.develop_the_civic_capacities_of_individu: Develop the civic capacities of individuals, communities, and/or civil society organizations (e.g., increase understanding of public issues; strengthen social capital)
en.citizenship_building: Citizenship building (e.g., opportunities for people to learn about their rights and claim them)
en.civil_society_building: Civil society building (e.g., network building across governmental and social boundaries)
en.cogovernance: Co-governance (e.g., collaboration in decision making with government and public bodies)
en.coproduction_in_form_of_partnership_and/: Co-production in form of partnership and/or contract with government and/or public bodies (e.g., collaboration with government to provide affordable housing)
Co-production in form of partnership and/or contract with private organisations (e.g. collaboration with business or civil society)
en.independent_action: Independent action (without the participation of government or private bodies)
en.informal_engagement_by_intermediaries_wi: Informal engagement by intermediaries with nongovernmental authorities (e.g., bargaining and negotiation on behalf of marginalized sectors)
Informal engagement by intermediaries with political authorities (e.g., bargaining and negotiation on behalf of marginalized sectors )
en.leadership_development: Leadership development (e.g., individual and group capacity for civic engagement)
en.oversight_and_social_auditing: Oversight and social auditing (e.g., measuring and reporting organizational performance)
en.research_focus_groups: Research (e.g., public opinion surveys; focus groups; participatory action research)
en.social_mobilization: Social mobilization (e.g., community organizing; consciousness raising; political consumerism)
en.inform: Inform (provide the public with balanced and objective information to assist them in understanding the problem, alternatives, opportunities, and/or solutions)
en.consult: Consult (obtain public feedback on analyses, alternatives, and/or decisions)
en.involve: Involve (work directly with the public throughout the process to ensure that public concerns are understood and considered)
en.collaborate: Collaborate (partner with the public in each aspect of the decision including the development of alternatives and the identification of the preferred solution)
en.empower: Empower (place final decision-making in the hands of the public)
en.open_to_all_with_special_effort_to_recru: Open to all with special effort to recruit some groups (e.g., community organizing to recruit low-income earners)
en.limited_to_only_some_groups_or_individua: Limited to only some groups or individuals
en.written_briefing_materials_online_or_as_: Written briefing materials (online or as handouts)
en.no_information_was_provided_to_participa: No information was provided to participants
en.not_relevant_to_this_type_of_initiative: Not relevant to this type of initiative
en.if_voting_unknown: Unknown (i.e., we don’t know how the vote was conducted)
en.local_government: Local Government  (e.g. Village, Town, City, National Government)
en.changes_in_peoples_knowledge_attitudes_a: Changes in people’s knowledge, attitudes, and behavior
en.changes_in_public_policy: Changes in public policy (e.g. new laws or regulations)
en.changes_in_how_institutions_operate: Changes in how institutions operate (e.g. improved decision making)
en.changes_in_civic_capacities: Changes in civic capacities (e.g. improved community problem solving)
en.experts: Experts (e.g. Scientists, Engineers, Criminologists, Doctors, Lawyers)
en.stakeholder_organizations: Stakeholder Organizations (e.g., Community Groups, NGOs, Business Interests)
en.process_methods_box_text: Methods are all-encompassing project designs used to guide public participation in politics and governance, such as Citizen Juries, Deliberative Polling, and Participatory Budgeting.
en.primary_organizera_box_text: Provide information about additional organizers and sponsors of the initiative in the 'Originating Entities and Funding' section of the case narrative.
en.funder_box_text: Provide additional information about funders of the initiative in the 'Originating Entities and Funding' section of the case narrative.
en.changes_types_box_text: Provide additional detail in the "Influence, Outcomes, and Effects" section of the case narrative.
en.components_box_title: Here are a few examples of why an event or process could be considered a component of a more comprehensive initiative:
en.components_box_text:
• it is one of several phases or sessions that use very different methods as part of the same initiative;
  • it engages different subsets of participants in one or more of an initiative’s phases or sessions;
  • it is a repeat cycle of a similar process that took place at another time in the same geographic location;
  • it is one of many events held in different locations as part of a single participatory initiative;
  • etc.
en.has_components_box_text: If you can’t find the case you are looking for, please publish your current work, then use quick submit to publish the case you want to add as a component. Once your new case is published, return to this form to label it as a component of this case.
en.is_component_of_box_title: Make this case a component of another case
en.is_component_of_box_text: If you can’t find the case you are looking for, please publish your current work, then use quick submit to publish the case you want to label this case as a component of. Once your new case is published, return to this form and label this case as a component of your new case.
en.evaluation_links_instructional: Provide links to evaluation reports here.
en.evaluation_links_placeholder: Provide a link to a evaluation report here.
en.components_intro: Some cases of public participation can be viewed as “components” of a single, overarching case. Any case can have multiple components, but can only be labeled as a component of a single case.
en.has_components_instructional_case: A case can have multiple components, but they must already be published cases on Participedia. Type to search for an existing case in Participedia to label it as a component of this case. Select one or more.
en.is_component_of_instructional: A case can only be a component of one other case, and the other case must already be published on Participedia. Type to search for an existing case in Participedia to label this case as a component of it. Select one.
